questions.question: Which of the following statements about diverticulitis is incorrect? Diverticulitis often presents with abdominal pain localized to the lower left side. A barium enema is a preferred imaging method for diagnosing diverticulitis. Colostomy is often performed as a first-line treatment. Stage Ib of the Modified Hinchey Classification refers to a pericolic abscess. Complications of diverticulitis may include fistula formation, such as colovesical fistula.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 2 and 3 Explanation: Diverticulitis Definition Inflammation or infection of diverticula in the colon. Etiology Obstruction (fecal matter or food): Trapped fecal matter or food causes pressure and inflammation. Bacterial infection: Infection occurs when bacteria proliferate in obstructed diverticula. Pathophysiology Increased pressure from trapped fecal matter can lead to inflammation, infection, and sometimes perforation of the diverticula. Symptoms Abdominal pain (lower left side) (Statement 1 ruled out) Fever Nausea, vomiting Change in bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation) Tenderness on examination Diagnosis CT Scan (IOC): Preferred for detailed imaging of the colon, identifying inflammation and abscesses. Ultrasound: Can detect inflammation and abscesses, but less detailed than CT. Blood Tests: Elevated white blood cell count suggests infection or inflammation. Barium Enema (contraindicated) (Statement 2): Should be avoided as it can worsen symptoms. Management Antibiotics Pain management (analgesics) Dietary modifications (clear liquids, then low-fiber, high-fiber) Surgery (for severe cases or complications) Resection: Removal of the affected segment of the colon to treat severe diverticulitis or complications. Colostomy (Statement 3) : Creation of an abdominal opening for waste elimination, often used in severe cases. Drainage of Abscesses: Percutaneous or surgical methods to drain abscesses associated with diverticulitis. Modified Hinchey Classification (Severity of acute diverticulitis) Stage 0: Mild diverticulitis Stage I: Ia: Pericolic inflammation Ib: Pericolic abscess (Statement 4 ruled out) Stage II: Pelvic or intra-abdominal abscess Stage III: Purulent peritonitis Stage IV: Fecal peritonitis Complications Hemorrhage (painless and profuse) Perforation (can cause pericolic abscess) Intestinal Obstruction (large or small bowel) Fistula Formation (e.g., colovesical) (Statement 5 ruled out) Leads to frequent UTIs,

questions.question: Which variant of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis is associated with both colorectal cancer and brain tumors?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Turcot Syndrome Explanation: Turcot syndrome is associated with both colorectal cancer and brain tumors. Variants of FAP: Classic FAP (Option A) Most common form with extensive polyps Attenuated FAP (Option B) Milder form with fewer polyps Gardner syndrome (Option C) Classic FAP + additional tumors Turcot syndrome (Option D) FAP variant with brain tumor Gardner Syndrome Turcot Syndrome Autosomal dominant variant Autosomal recessive variant Associated with Osteoma Congenital Hypertrophy of retinal Pigment Epithelium(CHRPE) Desmoid tumor Epidermoid cyst Supernumerary teeth Benign lymphoid polyposis of ileum Sebaceous cyst Associated with brain tumors in both FAP and lynch syndrome In FAP, causes Medulloblastoma. In lynch syndrome, causes Glioblastoma multiforme.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent colorectal cancer. Her family history reveals that her mother was diagnosed with endometrial cancer at age 50, and her aunt had ovarian cancer. Genetic testing is recommended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lynch Syndrome Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is Lynch syndrome/Hereditary Non Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC) Pathophysiology: Autosomal dominant condition caused by inherited mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6 and PMS2) which code for mismatch repair protein (MMR) leading to microsatellite instability. In high risk cases, it often develops before the age of 50 years. Endometrial cancer, Ovarian cancer and increased risk of stomach, intestinal cancers. Diagnosis based on Amsterdam and Bethesda criteria. Amsterdam II Criteria Three or more family members with Lynch syndrome related cancer, one of whom is a 1° relative. Two or more successive affected generations. At least one tumor diagnosed before 50 years. FAP excluded Testing for microsatellite instability (MSI) and immunohistochemistry (IHC) to assess the presence of MMR proteins in tumor tissues. Endoscopic Polypectomy Extended Colectomy in case of MLH1 and MLH2 carrier. Cowden Syndrome (Option A), Although it involves endometrial cancer, it is not typically associated with a high risk of colorectal cancer alone as prominently as Lynch Syndrome. Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (Option C) characterized by gastrointestinal polyps but not specifically associated with a combination of colorectal, endometrial, and ovarian cancers. MUTYH-Associated Polyposis (MAP) (Option D) characterized by the development of multiple colorectal polyps but does not typically involve a significant risk of endometrial or ovarian cancers. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1358

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with multiple oral papillomas, facial trichilemmomas, and a history of thyroid nodules. She also reports that her mother had breast cancer at a young age. On examination, multiple small, wart-like growths on her hands is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cowden disease Explanation : The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is Cowden disease. Cowden disease / Multiple Hamartomas: Loss of PTEN function leads to activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, promoting cell proliferation and survival. Clinical manifestations such as Hamartomas , Trichilemmomas, papillomatous papules, and acral keratoses, Oral papillomas, Multinodular goiter, adenomas. Patients need to have two major criteria to be diagnosed with Cowden disease. (One of the two must be either Lhermitte-Duclos disease or macrocephaly.) Lhermitte-Duclos disease Thyroid carcinoma Macrocephaly Breast cancer Treatment: Surveillance, Removal of symptomatic hamartomas or cancers and Cutaneous lesion treated with surgical excision and 5-fluorouracil. Neurofibromatosis (Option A) is characterized by café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas. It does not typically present with oral papillomas, trichilemmomas, or a family history of breast cancer. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (Option C) is characterized by gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation. It does not present with the features such as oral papillomas and trichilemmomas. Gardner syndrome (Option D) involves colorectal polyps, osteomas and epidermoid cysts. It does not present with oral papillomas or trichilemmomas.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension along with tenderness. X-ray shows dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels. The patient is taken for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following structures is most likely to be visualized first to differentiate between small intestine and large intestine obstruction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cecum Explanation: The cecum, located in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, is the first part of the large intestine and is typically the first structure visualized during surgery for suspected intestinal obstruction. It helps in differentiating between small and large intestine obstructions: Dilated cecum: Indicates a large bowel obstruction, as it is proximal to the blockage. Collapsed cecum with dilated small intestines: Suggests a small bowel obstruction. Identifying the cecum first allows surgeons to accurately determine the obstruction site and guide appropriate surgical management. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 913. Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 1189.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. A CT scan reveals a large intestinal obstruction at the level of the descending colon. Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for providing collateral circulation in this situation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Marginal Artery of Drummond Explanation: Marginal artery of Drummond is primarily responsible for providing collateral circulation in intestinal obstruction. Anatomy of the Large Intestine Segments: Cecum Connects to the ileum via the ileocecal valve, located in the lower right abdomen. Ascending Colon Runs upward on the right side of the abdomen to the hepatic flexure. Transverse Colon Extends horizontally across the abdomen from the hepatic flexure to the splenic flexure. Descending Colon Travels downward on the left side from the splenic flexure to the sigmoid colon. Sigmoid Colon S-shaped section connecting the descending colon to the rectum. Rectum Stores fecal matter before expulsion. Anus Terminal part of the digestive tract, through which feces are expelled. Blood and Nerve supply of the Large Intestine Arterial Supply Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA): Supplies the cecum, ascending colon, and proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon. (Option A) Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA): Supplies the distal one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum. (Option B) Marginal Artery of Drummond: An important arterial anastomosis running along the inner border of the colon, connecting branches of the SMA and IMA, ensuring continuous blood supply and providing collateral circulation. (Option C) Arc of Riolan / Meandering mesenteric artery: It is a collateral branch running close to the mesentery, connecting superior mesenteric artery to inferior mesenteric artery. It also connects proximal part of middle colic artery to left colic artery (Option D) Venous Drainage Blood from the colon drains into the superior mesenteric vein and inferior mesenteric vein , which then drain into the portal vein leading to the liver. Lymphatic Drainage Lymph from the colon drains into the mesenteric lymph nodes and ultimately into the thoracic duct. Nerve Supply Parasympathetic Supply: Vagus nerve: Up to the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon. Pelvic splanchnic nerves: From the distal one-third of the transverse colon onward. Sympathetic Supply: Superior and inferior mesenteric plexuses.

questions.question: Assertion: The colon plays a significant role in the production of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) from dietary fibers. Reason: Fermentation of dietary fibers by gut bacteria in the colon produces SCFAs like butyrate, acetate, and propionate, which serve as metabolic fuel for colon cells.

options.A: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
options.B: Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
options.C: The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.
options.D: Both Assertion and Reason are false

questions.explanation: for the Assertion. Correct Answer: A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion. Explanation: Physiological functions of the colon Function Description Water and Electrolyte Absorption Absorbs water, sodium (Na+), and chloride (Cl-) to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance. Secretion Secretes potassium (K+), bicarbonate (HCO3-), and mucus to protect mucosa and facilitate fecal passage. Fermentation and SCFA Production Ferments dietary fibers to produce short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) like butyrate, acetate, and propionate, which serve as metabolic fuel for colon cells. The right colon, particularly the cecum, is the primary fermentation site. (Option A) Storage and Dehydration of Stool The left colon stores fecal matter and absorbs water to form solid stools. Vitamin Production Gut bacteria synthesize vitamins such as vitamin K and some B vitamins, which are absorbed by the colon. Protection and Immunity Provides a barrier against pathogens through mucus, epithelial tight junctions, and immune cells. Motility and Transit Exhibits peristaltic movements to mix contents and move them toward the rectum. Mass peristalsis propels fecal matter for defecation. Regulation of pH Absorbs SCFAs and secretes bicarbonate to maintain optimal pH for bacterial activity and colonic function. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 476. G. K Pal, Comprehensive textbook of medical physiology, 1st Edition, Page 423. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 1263,1264.

questions.question: A 2-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended, and a digital rectal examination reveals a tight anal sphincter with an explosive discharge of stool upon withdrawal of the finger. What is the best step of investigation to confirm the exact pathology?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Rectal biopsy Explanation: Rectal biopsy is the investigation of choice for Hirschprung’s disease. Hirschsprung's Disease Introduction Congenital disorder known as congenital aganglionic megacolon or aganglionosis. Pathophysiology Absence of ganglion cells in myenteric (Auerbach) and submucosal (Meissner) plexuses. Continuous contraction of the affected bowel segment, leading to functional obstruction. Leads to proximal bowel dilatation and hypertrophy due to chronic obstruction. Typically affects the rectosigmoid region but can involve the entire colon in severe cases. CLINICAL PRESENTATION Neonates: Failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours. Abdominal distension. Bilious vomiting Infants and Children Chronic constipation Poor feeding Failure to thrive Enterocolitis (fever, diarrhea, and abdominal distension) DIAGNOSIS Clinical Evaluation History and physical examination indicating chronic constipation and failure to pass meconium. Radiological Abdominal X-ray: Shows dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels. (Option A) Contrast (Barium) Enema: Demonstrates a transition zone between dilated proximal and narrow distal bowel. (Option B) Rectal Biopsy Gold standard and IOC for diagnosis, showing the absence of ganglion cells. (Option C) Anorectal Manometry Shows lack of rectoanal inhibitory reflex. (Option D) MANAGEMENT Initial Management Stabilization with fluid resuscitation and decompression of the colon. Antibiotics for enterocolitis if present. Definitive Surgical Treatment Pull-Through Procedures: Removal of the aganglionic segment and pulling through the normal bowel to the anus. Swenson Procedure: Resection of the aganglionic segment with anastomosis to the anus. Duhamel Procedure: Ganglionic bowel brought down behind the aganglionic segment, side-to-side anastomosis. Soave Procedure: Removing the mucosa of the aganglionic segment, pulling the ganglionic bowel through the muscular cuff.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing. He gives a history of gastrointestinal discomfort and was recently diagnosed with both hiatal hernia and diverticulosis during a routine endoscopic examination. Given his current history, what is the other condition that has the highest probability for which he should be evaluated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gallstones Explanation: The given condition is suggestive of Saint’s triad, therefore, gallstones should be evaluated. Saint's triad is a rare clinical syndrome that includes the following three conditions: Hiatal hernia: A condition where part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm muscle. Diverticulosis : The presence of diverticula in the colon. Gallstones: Solid particles that form from bile cholesterol and bilirubin in the gallbladder. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 879.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms of abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits. A barium enema is performed, which reveals a characteristic finding on imaging given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Diverticulosis Explanation: The given image shows saw tooth appearance indicating Diverticulosis. Diverticulosis Definition Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon. Etiology Diet: Low-fiber diet increases colon pressure. Age: More common in those over 60. Genetics: Family history may increase risk. Pathophysiology Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge. Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula. Characteristics False diverticula: Involve only the mucosa and submucosa. Multiple and acquired: Typically multiple and not congenital. Location: Most commonly in the

questions.question: Which of the following correctly identifies a type of non-neoplastic polyp?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Juvenile polyp Explanation: I Classification of Colorectal Polyps Neoplastic Polyps Non-Neoplastic Polyps Adenomatous Polyps (Adenomas) Tubular (Option A) Villous (Option D) Tubulovillous Inflammatory Polyps Associated with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis) Serrated Polyps Hyperplastic Polyps Sessile Serrated Adenomas (SSA/Ps) (Option B) Traditional Serrated Adenomas (TSAs) Hamartomatous Polyps Juvenile Polyps: Usually in children, generally benign but associated with Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome. (Option C) Peutz-Jeghers Polyps: Associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, characterized by pigmentation around the mouth. Lymphoid Polyps Composed of lymphoid tissue, usually benign and associated with the immune response Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1355. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 1290,1291. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 889.

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl presents with intermittent abdominal pain, occasional rectal bleeding, and pigmented macules on her lips, buccal mucosa, and digits. Her mother had similar pigmented spots. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome Explanation The most likely diagnosis of the above condition is Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome. Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome: It is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene located on chromosome 19p13.3. Clinical Features Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Intermittent abdominal pain due to intussusception or obstruction by polyps, rectal bleeding, iron-deficiency anemia. Mucocutaneous Pigmentation: Dark blue to dark brown macules on the lips, buccal mucosa, and digits, Pigmented lesions may also appear around the eyes, nostrils and anus Cancer Risks: Increased risk of gastrointestinal, pancreatic, breast, ovarian, cervical, and testicular cancers Diagnosis Endoscopic evaluation: Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to identify and biopsy polyps Imaging: MRI, CT, or capsule endoscopy for small bowel visualization and to detect polyps not accessible by traditional endoscopy Genetic testing: Identification of STK11 gene mutations confirms the diagnosis Treatment Surveillance: Regular endoscopic surveillance to monitor and remove polyps to prevent complications like intussusception and bleeding Polyp Management: Endoscopic polypectomy for symptomatic or large polyps, Surgical intervention in cases of recurrent intussusception, significant bleeding, or obstruction Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) (Option A) is an inherited disorder characterized by the development of thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, typically appearing in adolescence.However, it lacks the characteristic pigmented macules. Lynch Syndrome (Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer) (Option B) is an inherited disorder that increases the risk of colorectal cancer and other cancers, often at a younger age but no mucocutaneous pigmented macules. Cowden Syndrome (Option D) is a g enetic disorder characterized by multiple non cancerous but does not typically present with pigmented macules.

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to rectal bleeding. His father died of colon cancer at age 40. Colonoscopy reveals hundreds of polyps throughout the colon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in the above condition is FAP ( familial adenomatous polyposis) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP): Caused Autosomal dominant mutation in the APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene on chromosome 5q21. 100% risk of colorectal cancer in those with APC gene mutation. 80% cases are from positive family history. Clinical Features: Numerous (>100) colorectal adenomatous polyps, typically developing in adolescence or early adulthood Rectal bleeding, diarrhea, abdominal pain Extracolonic manifestations : Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), desmoid tumors, upper gastrointestinal polyps, epidermoid cyst (Gardner syndrome) Increased risk of other cancers: duodenal, thyroid, brain (medulloblastoma), hepatoblastoma Diagnosis: Colonoscopy showing >100 polyps and biopsy showing adenomatous variety of polyp. Treatment: The aim of Surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer. Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis. Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA) Total proctocolectomy and end-ileostomy. Crohn's disease (Option A), While it can cause rectal bleeding, it doesn't typically present with numerous polyps throughout the colon. Lynch syndrome/Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) (Option C) increases cancer risk but doesn't usually cause numerous polyps. The average age of onset is later than FAP. Juvenile polyposis syndrome (Option D) can cause multiple polyps, but they are typically hamartomatous rather than adenomatous, fewer in number than FAP.
